title: Southeastern Grocers Weighs a Sale; Florida grocer withdrew its initial public offering last year
text:
If a deal goes through, it would be another sign of consolidation in the U.S. supermarket sector. Kroger Co. and Albertsons Cos. agreed last month to combine in a $20 billion deal, saying the merger would boost their technology and scale and help the companies compete better against bigger rivals. Kroger and Albertsons said they expect to divest stores to secure regulatory approval; that process is in early stages.

Southeastern Grocers, which runs about 420 stores primarily in the Southern U.S., was expected to generate about $9.6 billion in sales in 2020, according to the company's filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission related to the planned initial public offering.

The company also operates more than 200 pharmacies and 140 liquor stores. Southeastern's primary market is Florida, where it competes against Publix Super Markets Inc., Walmart Inc. and Aldi Inc. among others.

A Southeastern spokeswoman said that the company is always reviewing ways to enhance shareholder value and that it has an obligation to consider transactions that do so. She said the company will remain focused on its strategy.

Updates to follow as news develops.

Southeastern Grocers Weighs a Sale
